an4.3:1.1.pli: “Catūhi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato bālo abyatto asappuriso khataṃ upahataṃ attānaṃ pariharati, sāvajjo ca hoti sānuvajjo ca viññūnaṃ, bahuñca apuññaṃ pasavati.
an4.3:1.1.eng: “When a foolish, incompetent untrue person has four qualities they keep themselves broken and damaged. They deserve to be blamed and criticized by sensible people, and they brim with much wickedness.

an4.3:1.3.eng: Without examining or scrutinizing, they praise those deserving of criticism,

an4.3:1.4.eng: and they criticize those deserving of praise.

an4.3:1.5.pli: ananuvicca apariyogāhetvā appasādanīye ṭhāne pasādaṃ upadaṃseti,
an4.3:1.5.eng: They arouse faith in things that are dubious,

an4.3:1.6.pli: ananuvicca apariyogāhetvā pasādanīye ṭhāne appasādaṃ upadaṃseti—
an4.3:1.6.eng: and they don’t arouse faith in things that are inspiring.

an4.3:1.7.pli: imehi kho, bhikkhave, catūhi dhammehi samannāgato bālo abyatto asappuriso khataṃ upahataṃ attānaṃ pariharati, sāvajjo ca hoti sānuvajjo ca viññūnaṃ, bahuñca apuññaṃ pasavati.
an4.3:1.7.eng: When a foolish, incompetent untrue person possesses these four qualities they keep themselves broken and damaged. They deserve to be blamed and criticized by sensible people, and they brim with much wickedness.

an4.3:2.1.pli: Catūhi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato paṇḍito viyatto sappuriso akkhataṃ anupahataṃ attānaṃ pariharati, anavajjo ca hoti ananuvajjo ca viññūnaṃ, bahuñca puññaṃ pasavati.
an4.3:2.1.eng: When an astute, competent true person has four qualities they keep themselves intact and unscathed. They don’t deserve to be blamed and criticized by sensible people, and they brim with much merit.

an4.3:2.3.eng: After examining and scrutinizing, they criticize those deserving of criticism,

an4.3:2.4.eng: and they praise those deserving of praise.

an4.3:2.5.pli: anuvicca pariyogāhetvā appasādanīye ṭhāne appasādaṃ upadaṃseti,
an4.3:2.5.eng: They don’t arouse faith in things that are dubious,

an4.3:2.6.pli: anuvicca pariyogāhetvā pasādanīye ṭhāne pasādaṃ upadaṃseti—
an4.3:2.6.eng: and they do arouse faith in things that are inspiring.

an4.3:2.7.pli: imehi kho, bhikkhave, catūhi dhammehi samannāgato paṇḍito viyatto sappuriso akkhataṃ anupahataṃ attānaṃ pariharati, anavajjo ca hoti ananuvajjo ca viññūnaṃ, bahuñca puññaṃ pasavatīti.
an4.3:2.7.eng: When an astute, competent true person possesses these four qualities they keep themselves intact and unscathed. They don’t deserve to be blamed and criticized by sensible people, and they brim with much merit.

an4.3:3.1.eng: When you praise someone worthy of criticism,

an4.3:3.2.eng: or criticize someone worthy of praise,

an4.3:3.3.eng: you choose a losing hand with your own mouth:

an4.3:3.4.eng: you’ll never find happiness that way.

an4.3:4.1.eng: A losing hand at dice is a trivial thing,

an4.3:4.2.eng: if all you lose is your money

an4.3:4.3.eng: and all you own, even yourself.

an4.3:4.5.eng: is to hate the holy ones.

an4.3:5.1.eng: For a hundred thousand times a hundred million,

an4.3:5.2.eng: times five hundred and thirty-six times <j>a thousand times ten million years

an4.3:5.3.eng: a slanderer of noble ones goes to hell,

an4.3:5.4.eng: having aimed bad words and thoughts at them.”

an4.30:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati gijjhakūṭe pabbate.
an4.30:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, on the Vulture’s Peak Mountain.

an4.30:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena sambahulā abhiññātā abhiññātā paribbājakā sippinikātīre paribbājakārāme paṭivasanti, seyyathidaṃ annabhāro varadharo sakuludāyī ca paribbājako aññe ca abhiññātā abhiññātā paribbājakā.
an4.30:1.2.eng: Now at that time several very well-known wanderers were residing in the monastery of the wanderers on the bank of the Serpentine river. They included Annabhāra, Varadhara, Sakuludāyī, and other very well-known wanderers.

an4.30:1.3.pli: Atha kho bhagavā sāyanhasamayaṃ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito yena sippinikātīraṃ paribbājakārāmo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi. Nisajja kho bhagavā te paribbājake etadavoca:
an4.30:1.3.eng: Then in the late afternoon, the Buddha came out of retreat and went to the wanderer’s monastery on the banks of the Serpentine river, He sat down on the seat spread out, and said to the wanderers:

an4.30:2.1.pli: “Cattārimāni, paribbājakā, dhammapadāni aggaññāni rattaññāni vaṃsaññāni porāṇāni asaṅkiṇṇāni asaṅkiṇṇapubbāni, na saṅkīyanti na saṅkīyissanti, appaṭikuṭṭhāni samaṇehi brāhmaṇehi viññūhi.
an4.30:2.1.eng: “Wanderers, these four footprints of the Dhamma are primordial, long-standing, traditional, and ancient. They are uncorrupted, as they have been since the beginning. They’re not being corrupted now nor will they be. Sensible ascetics and brahmins don’t look down on them.

an4.30:2.3.pli: Anabhijjhā, paribbājakā, dhammapadaṃ aggaññaṃ rattaññaṃ vaṃsaññaṃ porāṇaṃ asaṅkiṇṇaṃ asaṅkiṇṇapubbaṃ, na saṅkīyati na saṅkīyissati, appaṭikuṭṭhaṃ samaṇehi brāhmaṇehi viññūhi.

an4.30:2.4.pli: Abyāpādo, paribbājakā, dhammapadaṃ …pe… sammāsati, paribbājakā, dhammapadaṃ …pe… sammāsamādhi, paribbājakā, dhammapadaṃ aggaññaṃ rattaññaṃ vaṃsaññaṃ porāṇaṃ asaṅkiṇṇaṃ asaṅkiṇṇapubbaṃ, na saṅkīyati na saṅkīyissati, appaṭikuṭṭhaṃ samaṇehi brāhmaṇehi viññūhi.
an4.30:2.4.eng: Good will … Right mindfulness … Right immersion …

an4.30:2.5.pli: Imāni kho, paribbājakā, cattāri dhammapadāni aggaññāni rattaññāni vaṃsaññāni porāṇāni asaṅkiṇṇāni asaṅkiṇṇapubbāni, na saṅkīyanti na saṅkīyissanti, appaṭikuṭṭhāni samaṇehi brāhmaṇehi viññūhi.
an4.30:2.5.eng: These four footprints of the Dhamma are primordial, long-standing, traditional, and ancient. They are uncorrupted, as they have been since the beginning. They’re not being corrupted now nor will they be. Sensible ascetics and brahmins don’t look down on them.

an4.30:3.2.pli: ‘ahametaṃ anabhijjhaṃ dhammapadaṃ paccakkhāya abhijjhāluṃ kāmesu tibbasārāgaṃ samaṇaṃ vā brāhmaṇaṃ vā paññāpessāmī’ti, tamahaṃ tattha evaṃ vadeyyaṃ:
an4.30:3.2.eng: ‘I’ll deny this Dhamma footprint of contentment, and describe a true ascetic or brahmin who covets sensual pleasures with acute lust.’ Then I’d say to them:

an4.30:3.3.eng: ‘Let them come, speak, and discuss. We’ll see how powerful they are.’

an4.30:3.4.pli: So vata, paribbājakā, anabhijjhaṃ dhammapadaṃ paccakkhāya abhijjhāluṃ kāmesu tibbasārāgaṃ samaṇaṃ vā brāhmaṇaṃ vā paññāpessatīti netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.
an4.30:3.4.eng: It is quite impossible to deny this Dhamma footprint of contentment, and point out a true ascetic or brahmin who covets sensual pleasures with acute lust.

an4.30:4.2.pli: ‘ahametaṃ abyāpādaṃ dhammapadaṃ paccakkhāya byāpannacittaṃ paduṭṭhamanasaṅkappaṃ samaṇaṃ vā brāhmaṇaṃ vā paññāpessāmī’ti, tamahaṃ tattha evaṃ vadeyyaṃ:
an4.30:4.2.eng: ‘I’ll deny this Dhamma footprint of good will, and describe a true ascetic or brahmin who has ill will and malicious intent.’ Then I’d say to them:

an4.30:4.3.eng: ‘Let them come, speak, and discuss. We’ll see how powerful they are.’

an4.30:4.4.pli: So vata, paribbājakā, abyāpādaṃ dhammapadaṃ paccakkhāya byāpannacittaṃ paduṭṭhamanasaṅkappaṃ samaṇaṃ vā brāhmaṇaṃ vā paññāpessatīti netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.
an4.30:4.4.eng: It is quite impossible to deny this Dhamma footprint of good will, and point out a true ascetic or brahmin who has ill will and malicious intent.

an4.30:5.2.pli: ‘ahametaṃ sammāsatiṃ dhammapadaṃ paccakkhāya muṭṭhassatiṃ asampajānaṃ samaṇaṃ vā brāhmaṇaṃ vā paññāpessāmī’ti, tamahaṃ tattha evaṃ vadeyyaṃ:
an4.30:5.2.eng: ‘I’ll deny this Dhamma footprint of right mindfulness, and describe a true ascetic or brahmin who is unmindful, with no situational awareness.’ Then I’d say to them:

an4.30:5.3.eng: ‘Let them come, speak, and discuss. We’ll see how powerful they are.’

an4.30:5.4.pli: So vata, paribbājakā, sammāsatiṃ dhammapadaṃ paccakkhāya muṭṭhassatiṃ asampajānaṃ samaṇaṃ vā brāhmaṇaṃ vā paññāpessatīti netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.
an4.30:5.4.eng: It is quite impossible to deny this Dhamma footprint of right mindfulness, and point out a true ascetic or brahmin who is unmindful, with no situational awareness.

an4.30:6.2.pli: ‘ahametaṃ sammāsamādhiṃ dhammapadaṃ paccakkhāya asamāhitaṃ vibbhantacittaṃ samaṇaṃ vā brāhmaṇaṃ vā paññāpessāmī’ti, tamahaṃ tattha evaṃ vadeyyaṃ:
an4.30:6.2.eng: ‘I’ll deny this Dhamma footprint of right immersion, and describe a true ascetic or brahmin who is scattered, with straying mind.’ Then I’d say to them:

an4.30:6.3.eng: ‘Let them come, speak, and discuss. We’ll see how powerful they are.’

an4.30:6.4.pli: So vata, paribbājakā, sammāsamādhiṃ dhammapadaṃ paccakkhāya asamāhitaṃ vibbhantacittaṃ samaṇaṃ vā brāhmaṇaṃ vā paññāpessatīti netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.
an4.30:6.4.eng: It is quite impossible to deny this Dhamma footprint of right immersion, and point out a true ascetic or brahmin who is scattered, with straying mind.

an4.30:7.1.pli: Yo kho, paribbājakā, imāni cattāri dhammapadāni garahitabbaṃ paṭikkositabbaṃ maññeyya, tassa diṭṭheva dhamme cattāro sahadhammikā vādānupātā gārayhā ṭhānā āgacchanti.
an4.30:7.1.eng: If anyone imagines they can criticize and reject these four footprints of the Dhamma, they deserve rebuttal and criticism on four legitimate grounds in this very life.

an4.30:7.3.pli: Anabhijjhañce bhavaṃ dhammapadaṃ garahati paṭikkosati, ye ca hi abhijjhālū kāmesu tibbasārāgā samaṇabrāhmaṇā te bhoto pujjā te bhoto pāsaṃsā.
an4.30:7.3.eng: If you reject the Dhamma footprint of contentment, then you must honor and praise those ascetics and brahmins who covet sensual pleasures with acute lust.

an4.30:7.4.pli: Abyāpādañce bhavaṃ dhammapadaṃ garahati paṭikkosati, ye ca hi byāpannacittā paduṭṭhamanasaṅkappā samaṇabrāhmaṇā te bhoto pujjā te bhoto pāsaṃsā.
an4.30:7.4.eng: If you reject the Dhamma footprint of good will, you must honor and praise those ascetics and brahmins who have ill will and malicious intent.

an4.30:7.5.pli: Sammāsatiñce bhavaṃ dhammapadaṃ garahati paṭikkosati, ye ca hi muṭṭhassatī asampajānā samaṇabrāhmaṇā te bhoto pujjā te bhoto pāsaṃsā.
an4.30:7.5.eng: If you reject the Dhamma footprint of right mindfulness, then you must honor and praise those ascetics and brahmins who are unmindful, with no situational awareness.

an4.30:7.6.pli: Sammāsamādhiñce bhavaṃ dhammapadaṃ garahati paṭikkosati, ye ca hi asamāhitā vibbhantacittā samaṇabrāhmaṇā te bhoto pujjā te bhoto pāsaṃsā.
an4.30:7.6.eng: If you reject the Dhamma footprint of right immersion, you must honor and praise those ascetics and brahmins who are scattered, with straying minds.

an4.30:8.1.pli: Yo kho, paribbājakā, imāni cattāri dhammapadāni garahitabbaṃ paṭikkositabbaṃ maññeyya, tassa diṭṭheva dhamme ime cattāro sahadhammikā vādānupātā gārayhā ṭhānā āgacchanti.
an4.30:8.1.eng: If anyone imagines they can criticize and reject these four footprints of the Dhamma, they deserve rebuttal and criticism on four legitimate grounds in this very life.

an4.30:8.2.pli: Yepi te, paribbājakā, ahesuṃ ukkalā vassabhaññā ahetukavādā akiriyavādā natthikavādā, tepi imāni cattāri dhammapadāni na garahitabbaṃ na paṭikkositabbaṃ amaññiṃsu.
an4.30:8.2.eng: Even those those who were loud and bold advocates of the doctrines of no-cause, inaction, and nihilism didn’t imagine that these four footprints of the Dhamma should be criticized or rejected.

an4.30:8.4.eng: For fear of being blamed, provoked, and faulted.

an4.30:9.1.eng: One who has good will, ever mindful,

an4.304-783:1.1.pli: “Dosassa …pe… mohassa … kodhassa … upanāhassa … makkhassa … paḷāsassa … issāya … macchariyassa … māyāya … sāṭheyyassa … thambhassa … sārambhassa … mānassa … atimānassa … madassa … pamādassa abhiññāya … pariññāya … parikkhayāya … pahānāya … khayāya … vayāya … virāgāya … nirodhāya … cāgāya … paṭinissaggāya ime cattāro dhammā bhāvetabbā”ti.
an4.304-783:1.1.eng: “Of hate … delusion … anger … acrimony … disdain … contempt … jealousy … stinginess … deceit … deviousness … obstinacy … aggression … conceit … arrogance … vanity … negligence … for insight … complete understanding … finishing … giving up … ending … vanishing … fading away … cessation … giving away … letting go … four things should be developed.”

an4.304-783:1.5.eng: The Book of the Fours is finished.

an4.31:1.1.pli: “Cattārimāni, bhikkhave, cakkāni, yehi samannāgatānaṃ devamanussānaṃ catucakkaṃ vattati, yehi samannāgatā devamanussā nacirasseva mahantattaṃ vepullattaṃ pāpuṇanti bhogesu.
an4.31:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these four situations. When these situations come about, any god or human who takes advantage of them will soon acquire great and abundant wealth.

an4.31:1.3.pli: Patirūpadesavāso, sappurisāvassayo, attasammāpaṇidhi, pubbe ca katapuññatā—
an4.31:1.3.eng: Living in a suitable region, relying on true persons, being rightly resolved in oneself, and past merit.

an4.31:1.4.pli: Imāni kho, bhikkhave, cattāri cakkāni, yehi samannāgatānaṃ devamanussānaṃ catucakkaṃ vattati, yehi samannāgatā devamanussā nacirasseva mahantattaṃ vepullattaṃ pāpuṇanti bhogesūti.
an4.31:1.4.eng: These are the four situations. When these situations come about, any god or human who takes advantage of them will soon acquire great and abundant wealth.

an4.31:2.1.eng: When a man lives in a suitable region,

an4.31:2.4.eng: and having merit from the past,

an4.32:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these four ways of being inclusive.

an4.32:1.3.eng: Giving, kindly words, taking care, and equality.

an4.32:1.4.eng: These are the four ways of being inclusive.

an4.32:2.3.eng: and treating equally in worldly conditions,

an4.32:2.4.eng: as they deserve in each case.

an4.32:2.5.eng: These ways of being inclusive in the world

an4.32:2.6.eng: are like a moving chariot’s linchpin.

an4.32:3.1.eng: If there were no such ways of being inclusive,

an4.32:3.4.eng: for what they’ve done for their children.

an4.32:4.1.eng: But since these ways of being inclusive do exist,

an4.32:4.2.eng: the astute do regard them well,

an4.33:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, towards evening the lion, king of beasts, emerges from his den,

an4.33:1.4.pli: Samantā catuddisā anuviloketvā tikkhattuṃ sīhanādaṃ nadati.
an4.33:1.4.eng: and roars his lion’s roar three times.

an4.33:1.5.eng: Then he sets out on the hunt.

an4.33:1.6.pli: Ye kho pana te, bhikkhave, tiracchānagatā pāṇā sīhassa migarañño nadato saddaṃ suṇanti, te yebhuyyena bhayaṃ saṃvegaṃ santāsaṃ āpajjanti.
an4.33:1.6.eng: And the animals who hear the roar of the lion, king of beasts, are typically filled with fear, awe, and terror.

an4.33:1.7.pli: Bilaṃ bilāsayā pavisanti, dakaṃ dakāsayā pavisanti, vanaṃ vanāsayā pavisanti, ākāsaṃ pakkhino bhajanti.
an4.33:1.7.eng: They return to their lairs, be they in a hole, the water, or a wood; and the birds take to the air.

an4.33:1.8.pli: Yepi te, bhikkhave, rañño nāgā gāmanigamarājadhānīsu daḷhehi varattehi bandhanehi baddhā, tepi tāni bandhanāni sañchinditvā sampadāletvā bhītā muttakarīsaṃ cajamānā yena vā tena vā palāyanti.
an4.33:1.8.eng: Even the royal elephants, bound with strong harnesses in the villages, towns, and capital cities, break apart their bonds, and urinate and defecate in terror as they flee here and there.

an4.33:1.9.pli: Evaṃ mahiddhiko kho, bhikkhave, sīho migarājā tiracchānagatānaṃ pāṇānaṃ, evaṃ mahesakkho evaṃ mahānubhāvo.
an4.33:1.9.eng: That’s how powerful is the lion, king of beasts, over animals, how illustrious and mighty.

an4.33:2.1.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, yadā tathāgato loke uppajjati arahaṃ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavā, so dhammaṃ deseti:
an4.33:2.1.eng: In the same way, when a Realized One arises in the world—perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed—he teaches the Dhamma:

an4.33:2.2.pli: ‘iti sakkāyo, iti sakkāyasamudayo, iti sakkāyanirodho, iti sakkāyanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti.
an4.33:2.2.eng: ‘Such is substantial reality, such is the origin of substantial reality, such is the cessation of substantial reality, such is the practice that leads to the cessation of substantial reality.’

an4.33:2.3.pli: Yepi te, bhikkhave, devā dīghāyukā vaṇṇavanto sukhabahulā uccesu vimānesu ciraṭṭhitikā, tepi tathāgatassa dhammadesanaṃ sutvā yebhuyyena bhayaṃ saṃvegaṃ santāsaṃ āpajjanti:
an4.33:2.3.eng: Now, there are gods who are long-lived, beautiful, and very happy, lasting long in their divine palaces. When they hear this teaching by the Realized One, they’re typically filled with fear, awe, and terror.

an4.33:2.4.pli: ‘aniccā vata kira, bho, mayaṃ samānā niccamhāti amaññimha;
an4.33:2.4.eng: ‘Oh no! It turns out we’re impermanent, though we thought we were permanent!

an4.33:2.5.pli: addhuvā vata kira, bho, mayaṃ samānā dhuvamhāti amaññimha;
an4.33:2.5.eng: It turns out we don’t last, though we thought we were everlasting!

an4.33:2.6.pli: asassatā vata kira, bho, mayaṃ samānā sassatamhāti amaññimha.
an4.33:2.6.eng: It turns out we’re transient, though we thought we were eternal!

an4.33:2.7.pli: Mayaṃ kira, bho, aniccā addhuvā asassatā sakkāyapariyāpannā’ti.
an4.33:2.7.eng: It turns out that we’re impermanent, not lasting, transient, and included within substantial reality.’

an4.33:2.8.pli: Evaṃ mahiddhiko kho, bhikkhave, tathāgato sadevakassa lokassa, evaṃ mahesakkho evaṃ mahānubhāvoti.
an4.33:2.8.eng: That’s how powerful is the Realized One in the world with its gods, how illustrious and mighty.

an4.33:3.2.eng: in all the world with its gods,

an4.33:3.3.eng: rolls forth the Wheel of Dhamma

an4.33:4.4.eng: that leads to the stilling of suffering.

an4.33:5.3.eng: are afraid and full of terror,

an4.33:5.4.eng: like the other beasts when they hear a lion.

an4.33:6.3.eng: So they say when they hear the word

an4.33:6.4.eng: of the perfected one, free and unaffected.”

an4.34:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, these four kinds of confidence are the best.

an4.34:1.3.pli: Yāvatā, bhikkhave, sattā apadā vā dvipadā vā catuppadā vā bahuppadā vā rūpino vā arūpino vā saññino vā asaññino vā nevasaññināsaññino vā, tathāgato tesaṃ aggamakkhāyati arahaṃ sammāsambuddho.
an4.34:1.3.eng: The Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha, is said to be the best of all sentient beings—be they footless, with two feet, four feet, or many feet; with form or formless; with perception or without perception or with neither perception nor non-perception.

an4.34:1.4.pli: Ye, bhikkhave, buddhe pasannā, agge te pasannā.
an4.34:1.4.eng: Those who have confidence in the Buddha have confidence in the best.

an4.34:1.5.pli: Agge kho pana pasannānaṃ aggo vipāko hoti.
an4.34:1.5.eng: Having confidence in the best, the result is the best.

an4.34:2.1.pli: Yāvatā, bhikkhave, dhammā saṅkhatā, ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo tesaṃ aggamakkhāyati.
an4.34:2.1.eng: The noble eightfold path is said to be the best of all conditioned things.

an4.34:2.2.pli: Ye, bhikkhave, ariye aṭṭhaṅgike magge pasannā, agge te pasannā.
an4.34:2.2.eng: Those who have confidence in the noble eightfold path have confidence in the best.

an4.34:2.3.pli: Agge kho pana pasannānaṃ aggo vipāko hoti.
an4.34:2.3.eng: Having confidence in the best, the result is the best.

an4.34:3.1.pli: Yāvatā, bhikkhave, dhammā saṅkhatā vā asaṅkhatā vā, virāgo tesaṃ aggamakkhāyati, yadidaṃ madanimmadano pipāsavinayo ālayasamugghāto vaṭṭupacchedo taṇhākkhayo virāgo nirodho nibbānaṃ.
an4.34:3.1.eng: Fading away is said to be the best of all things whether conditioned or unconditioned. That is, the quelling of vanity, the removing of thirst, the abolishing of clinging, the breaking of the round, the ending of craving, fading away, cessation, extinguishment.

an4.34:3.2.pli: Ye, bhikkhave, virāge dhamme pasannā, agge te pasannā.
an4.34:3.2.eng: Those who have confidence in the teaching of fading away have confidence in the best.

an4.34:3.3.pli: Agge kho pana pasannānaṃ aggo vipāko hoti.
an4.34:3.3.eng: Having confidence in the best, the result is the best.

an4.34:4.1.pli: Yāvatā, bhikkhave, saṅghā vā gaṇā vā, tathāgatasāvakasaṅgho tesaṃ aggamakkhāyati, yadidaṃ cattāri purisayugāni aṭṭha purisapuggalā esa bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho āhuneyyo pāhuneyyo dakkhiṇeyyo añjalikaraṇīyo anuttaraṃ puññakkhettaṃ lokassa.
an4.34:4.1.eng: The Saṅgha of the Realized One’s disciples is said to be the best of all communities and groups. It consists of the four pairs, the eight individual persons. This is the Saṅgha of the Buddha’s disciples that is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of greeting with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.

an4.34:4.2.pli: Ye, bhikkhave, saṅghe pasannā, agge te pasannā.
an4.34:4.2.eng: Those who have confidence in the Saṅgha have confidence in the best.

an4.34:4.3.pli: Agge kho pana pasannānaṃ aggo vipāko hoti.
an4.34:4.3.eng: Having confidence in the best, the result is the best.

an4.34:4.4.eng: These are the four best kinds of confidence.

an4.34:5.1.eng: For those who, knowing the best teaching,

an4.34:5.2.eng: base their confidence on the best—

an4.34:5.3.eng: confident in the best Awakened One,

an4.34:5.4.eng: supremely worthy of a religious donation;

an4.34:6.2.eng: the bliss of fading and stilling;

an4.34:8.1.eng: An intelligent person gives to the best,

an4.34:8.3.eng: When they become a god or human,

an4.34:8.4.eng: they rejoice at reaching the best.”
